title: I think that image models (such as ChatGPT) are probably a great fit for custom Zoom backgrounds
author: Ozzie Gooen
content:
Ozzie Gooen's Post

I think that image models (such as ChatGPT) are probably a great fit for custom Zoom backgrounds.

Some people spend a great deal of money and time on nice bookshelves and lighting for their backgrounds. But arguably, custom AI images would have a lot of benefits:

1. They can signal more information about you.
2. They can set the right vibe that you appreciate.
3. They are dramatically more accessible than fancy physical setups.

Here's one version I quickly made. The robot is aspirational, of course. Sadly, it didn't quite get the book titles right—I tried including a bunch of books that I've liked.

It will also be neat in the future to turn such things into videos. For example, in this case, having the trees blowing outside and maybe the robot doing cute tasks.

---

Comments:

Vipul Naik:  
So my naive prediction for the effect of Instagram filters and similar tools was that they would make people care less about their actual physical appearance, since they can always clean it up with a filter before posting. However, my impression is that this hasn't really happened.

Ozzie Gooen:  
That's interesting. But it's so counter-intuitive, I'd be skeptical of how much it generalizes. For example, a lot of people live and work in VR now. I'd expect that these people see great virtual environments, and I'd be very surprised if that didn't affect their preferences for their physical environments.

Vipul Naik:  
It could be that physical appearance touches an evolutionary chord (perhaps more so for people of reproductive age, and more so for females than males) in a way that home appearance doesn't.

Gina Stuessy:  
Neat idea. I think I wouldn't want to use a fake background with people I'm close to (like coworkers, family, friends), or people I might have an ongoing connection to, unless it was obvious to them that it was fake. And I hardly ever have one-off meetings with people I'm not close to.

As a bias detection expert, I approach this document by examining both the original post and the ensuing discussion for cognitive, social, and cultural biases. The post is speculative and opinion-based, which often invites confirmation bias, availability heuristic, and selection bias. The comments further introduce potential for motivated reasoning, in-group/out-group bias, and base rate neglect, especially as participants generalize from personal experience or limited observations. 

Key aspects to consider:
- The assumption that AI-generated backgrounds are 'dramatically more accessible' than physical setups may overlook digital divides or accessibility issues (selection bias, scope insensitivity).
- The discussion about Instagram filters and physical appearance generalizes from anecdotal impressions, risking base rate neglect and confirmation bias.
- The evolutionary explanation for physical appearance importance invokes just-so stories, which can reflect narrative fallacy and system justification bias.
- The social acceptability of fake backgrounds is discussed from a personal perspective, which may not generalize (false consensus effect).

I will focus on identifying where these and other biases manifest, their potential impact on reasoning, and suggest mitigation strategies.
